prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in computer science would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in computer science would. Let $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c}$ be three unit vectors, such that the angle between any of them is the acute angle $\theta.$  The volume of the tetrahedron generated by these three vectors is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{360}}.$  Find
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta.\]
gpt_response:
To begin, we note that the volume of a tetrahedron with sides of length $a,$ $b,$ and $c,$ can be expressed as
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{vmatrix}.\]In this case, the side lengths are all 1, so the volume of the tetrahedron is $\frac{1}{6}$ times the absolute value of the determinant of
\[\begin{pmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_x - 0 & b_x - 0 & c_x - 0 \\ a_y - 0 & b_y - 0 & c_y - 0 \\ a_z - 0 & b_z - 0 & c_z - 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{vmatrix} = \frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a \cdot (b \times c) & b \cdot (c \times a) & c \cdot (a \times b) \\ a \cdot a & b \cdot b & c \cdot c \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\]Since $\| \mathbf{a} \| = \| \mathbf{b} \| = \| \mathbf{c} \| = 1,$ the diagonal entries in the matrix on the right are all 1.  Also, if we let $\mathbf{a} = (a_1, a_2, a_3),$ $\mathbf{b} = (b_1, b_2, b_3),$ and $\mathbf{c} = (c_1, c_2, c_3),$ then
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\ a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ \end{vmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ c_3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} a_2 & a_3 \\ b_2 & b_3 \end{vmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_2 b_3 - a_3 b_2) c_1 - (a_1 b_3 - a_3 b_1) c_2 + (a_1 b_2 - a_2 b_1) c_3 = \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c},\]and
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{a} = a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 = 1.\]Therefore, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} & \mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} & \mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = \frac{1}{6} (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} + \mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} + \mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}).\]By the vector triple product identity, $\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c},$ so
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} = \mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c})) = \mathbf{a} \cdot ((\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{cb = \cos \theta.\]By similar methods, we can show that $\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} = \cos \theta$ and $\mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = \cos \theta,$ so the volume of the tetrahedron is $\frac{3 \cos \theta}{6} = \frac{1}{2} \cos \theta.$  Hence, $\cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3} \sqrt{2 \sqrt{360}}},$ making
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta = \frac{3}{6} - 2 \left(\frac{1}{6}\right) = \boxed{0}.\]
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \frac{9}{10}?: To begin, we note that the volume of a tetrahedron with sides of length $a,$ $b,$ and $c,$ can be expressed as
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{vmatrix}.\]In this case, the side lengths are all 1, so the volume of the tetrahedron is $\frac{1}{6}$ times the absolute value of the determinant of
\[\begin{pmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_x - 0 & b_x - 0 & c_x - 0 \\ a_y - 0 & b_y - 0 & c_y - 0 \\ a_z - 0 & b_z - 0 & c_z - 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a_x & b_x & c_x \\ a_y & b_y & c_y \\ a_z & b_z & c_z \end{vmatrix} = \frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} a \cdot (b \times c) & b \cdot (c \times a) & c \cdot (a \times b) \\ a \cdot a & b \cdot b & c \cdot c \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\]Since $\| \mathbf{a} \| = \| \mathbf{b} \| = \| \mathbf{c} \| = 1,$ the diagonal entries in the matrix on the right are all 1.  Also, if we let $\mathbf{a} = (a_1, a_2, a_3),$ $\mathbf{b} = (b_1, b_2, b_3),$ and $\mathbf{c} = (c_1, c_2, c_3),$ then
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\ a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ \end{vmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ c_3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} a_2 & a_3 \\ b_2 & b_3 \end{vmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_2 b_3 - a_3 b_2) c_1 - (a_1 b_3 - a_3 b_1) c_2 + (a_1 b_2 - a_2 b_1) c_3 = \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c},\]and
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{a} = a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 = 1.\]Therefore, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} & \mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} & \mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = \frac{1}{6} (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} + \mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} + \mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}).\]By the vector triple product identity, $\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c},$ so
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} = \mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c})) = \mathbf{a} \cdot ((\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{cb = \cos \theta.\]By similar methods, we can show that $\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a} = \cos \theta$ and $\mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = \cos \theta,$ so the volume of the tetrahedron is $\frac{3 \cos \theta}{6} = \frac{1}{2} \cos \theta.$  Hence, $\cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3} \sqrt{2 \sqrt{360}}},$ making
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta = \frac{3}{6} - 2 \left(\frac{1}{6}\right) = \boxed{0}.\]
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: No. The final solution obtained in the response is 0.
